author: _shemnon
content: <@508125616940515329> <@1011612262743679036> <@429719902363058177> do you have a CLI or script that can run arbitrary state or block test JSONs?  Or do these need to be loaded into your client build to execute?

author: draganrakita
content: There is binary to run statetests. Install rust, download revm repo, and use `cargo run --release -p revme statetest tests/eof_suite/state_tests/`. Executable if needed can be found at `~/target/release/revme`

author: gcolvin
content:
Is this being discussed elsewhere?
https://mariusvanderwijden.github.io/blog/2024/07/12/EOF/

author: gcolvin
content:
The part I care about, <@360491619402776577> is

> As long as the EVM contains non-static jumps, the analysis of a program is in the worst case O(n^2). EOF removes dynamic jumps which reduces the analysis to O(n) in the worst case.
> 
> Iâ€™m not convinced that that the difference is significant though, since EVM programs are inherently small in size. Even at the worst case of 24576 byte, the analysis needs ~600 million steps. Assuming 1000ns per step (which is quite a lot, for reference KECCAK takes <700ns on my machine) this can be analysis be done in 10 minutes.

author: gcolvin
content: But others have been convinced since 2016 that this is a problem.  EWasm was abandoned in part because JITing fuzzed codes could sometimes take seconds rather milliseconds.
